A.content: “my death,” a flashing light at every border, it’s awake, can always see a nightwatchman (du veilleur) or a nightlight (de la veilleuse)
A.linkedContent: “my death,” a flashing light at every border, it’s awake, can always see a nightwatchman (du veilleur) or a nightlight (de la veilleuse)

A.content: in crossing a border, one changes/exchanges death (on change le mort, on change de mort), one passes from figure of death as trespass (passage of line, transgression of border, pas au-delà) to another figure of border btwn life and death
A.linkedContent: in crossing a border, one changes/exchanges death (on change le mort, on change de mort), one passes from figure of death as trespass (passage of line, transgression of border, pas au-delà) to another figure of border btwn life and death

A.content: every culture characterized by way of its dealing w/, its “living” death as trespass
A.linkedContent: every culture characterized by way of its dealing w/, its “living” death as trespass

A.content: there is no culture of death itself or properly dying, dying neither entirely natural nor cultural
A.linkedContent: there is no culture of death itself or properly dying, dying neither entirely natural nor cultural

A.content: no culture, no medicine [pharmakon] w/out horizon of death
A.linkedContent: no culture, no medicine [pharmakon] w/out horizon of death

A.content: “culture of death”—a tautology? each culture treats death differently, w/ different partitions, culture of death = history of death (cult of ancestors, rituals of mourning/sacrifice)
A.linkedContent: “culture of death”—a tautology? each culture treats death differently, w/ different partitions, culture of death = history of death (cult of ancestors, rituals of mourning/sacrifice)

A.content: difference of animal/human, biological life/culture is the relation to death as such, true border would be there
A.linkedContent: difference of animal/human, biological life/culture is the relation to death as such, true border would be there

OH.content: what is proper to a culture is not to be identical to itself, culture of oneself as culture of other, gathered and divided at the heart, home: [violent syntax] différence (d’) avec soi
OH.linkedContent: what is proper to a culture is not to be identical to itself, culture of oneself as culture of other, gathered and divided at the heart, home: [violent syntax] différence (d’) avec soi

OH.content: culture of other: signals culture never has a single origin
OH.linkedContent: culture of other: signals culture never has a single origin

OH.content: monogenealogy: mystification in history of culture

every history, history of a culture, has a telos (promise, memory) toward which it dreams of gathering itself > anticipation & telos; and every history cannot be identified in advance, unanticipatable, non-masterable, that of which one has no memory
OH.linkedContent: every history, history of a culture, has a telos (promise, memory) toward which it dreams of gathering itself > anticipation & telos; and every history cannot be identified in advance, unanticipatable, non-masterable, that of which one has no memory

OH.content: identification is always cultural never natural, always has a capital form, advanced point, capitalizing reserve
OH.linkedContent: identification is always cultural never natural, always has a capital form, advanced point, capitalizing reserve

OH.content: Valéry: Mediterranean has been a veritable machine for making culture
OH.linkedContent: Valéry: Mediterranean has been a veritable machine for making culture

PPHS.content: acc. Hegel, phonetic alphabet most open to infinite development of tradition, most historic element of culture
PPHS.linkedContent: acc. Hegel, phonetic alphabet most open to infinite development of tradition, most historic element of culture

P.content: Kant: “happiness & culture presupposes that man puts to work what nature puts at his disposal”; Critique depends on reflexive humanism, pragmatic anthropology
P.linkedContent: Kant: “happiness & culture presupposes that man puts to work what nature puts at his disposal”; Critique depends on reflexive humanism, pragmatic anthropology

POS.content: taking seriously the systematic formation of our “culture” gives deconstruction its systematic character, avoids empiricism, improvisation, false discoveries
POS.linkedContent: taking seriously the systematic formation of our “culture” gives deconstruction its systematic character, avoids empiricism, improvisation, false discoveries

OTO.content: for Nietzsche, culture (Bildung) begins when we know how to treat the living as living; Derrida discusses a pact, alliance, contract, a hymen w/ living language, w/ mother (tongue), against death (father): even good master of history (science of the father) trains for the sake of mother tongue, must know when to suppress ‘historical interest’ for culture to begin
OTO.linkedContent: for Nietzsche, culture (Bildung) begins when we know how to treat the living as living; Derrida discusses a pact, alliance, contract, a hymen w/ living language, w/ mother (tongue), against death (father): even good master of history (science of the father) trains for the sake of mother tongue, must know when to suppress ‘historical interest’ for culture to begin

OTO.content: [re: signature w/out value, to which is juxtaposed untimely signature] Nietzsche: rights of genius have been democratized, everyone relieved of the labor to form oneself, of personal necessity of culture (Bildungsarbeit, Bildungsnot)
OTO.linkedContent: [re: signature w/out value, to which is juxtaposed untimely signature] Nietzsche: rights of genius have been democratized, everyone relieved of the labor to form oneself, of personal necessity of culture (Bildungsarbeit, Bildungsnot)

OTO.content: Nietzsche: culture (Bildung) begins w/ obedience (Gehorsamkeit), subordination (Unterordnung), discipline (Zucht), not academic freedom
OTO.linkedContent: Nietzsche: culture (Bildung) begins w/ obedience (Gehorsamkeit), subordination (Unterordnung), discipline (Zucht), not academic freedom

O.content: Hegel: “Bildung (culture) must leave room for the earnestness of life in its concrete richness; this leads the way to experience of the thing itself”
O.linkedContent: Hegel: “Bildung (culture) must leave room for the earnestness of life in its concrete richness; this leads the way to experience of the thing itself”

SW.content: “not in a hurry”: I am against those who prescribe the veil, against those who forbid it (same w/ circumcision) > people don’t realize any longer that the scholarly, secular, democratic belong to cultures of tallith & veil: contamination is everywhere
SW.linkedContent: “not in a hurry”: I am against those who prescribe the veil, against those who forbid it (same w/ circumcision) > people don’t realize any longer that the scholarly, secular, democratic belong to cultures of tallith & veil: contamination is everywhere

RGE.content: reading of Bataille: 1) must not isolate notions (“experience,” “interior”) as if they were their own context: error to remain blind [?] to a traditional culture wishing to be taken as natural element of discourse 2) must not submit contextual attentiveness to system of meaning promising absolute formal mastery (this would erase excess of nonmeaning)
RGE.linkedContent: reading of Bataille: 1) must not isolate notions (“experience,” “interior”) as if they were their own context: error to remain blind [?] to a traditional culture wishing to be taken as natural element of discourse 2) must not submit contextual attentiveness to system of meaning promising absolute formal mastery (this would erase excess of nonmeaning)

REST.content: marche almost same word as mark, margins, also Pas > necessity of walking, lowest degree, most subjective or underlying level of culture/institution: pair of shoes
REST.linkedContent: marche almost same word as mark, margins, also Pas > necessity of walking, lowest degree, most subjective or underlying level of culture/institution: pair of shoes

HST.content: hospitality: culture itself > les structure de l’accueil, les structures d’accueil
HST.linkedContent: hospitality: culture itself > les structure de l’accueil, les structures d’accueil

HST.content: no culture w/out culture of death says same thing as no culture w/out culture of hospitality: of the abode as last resting place (de la demeure comme dernieère demeure), mourning & memory
HST.linkedContent: no culture w/out culture of death says same thing as no culture w/out culture of hospitality: of the abode as last resting place (de la demeure comme dernieère demeure), mourning & memory

+R.content: “left-realism” (codified simplification or politicist stereotype) annuls scientific event, squeezing out thickness of culture, ideological efficacity [opposite of formalism?]
+R.linkedContent: “left-realism” (codified simplification or politicist stereotype) annuls scientific event, squeezing out thickness of culture, ideological efficacity [opposite of formalism?]

CF.content: ‘to cultivate an ethic of hospitality’: tautologous expression? hospitality is culture, ethics, residence, relation to ourselves & others
CF.linkedContent: ‘to cultivate an ethic of hospitality’: tautologous expression? hospitality is culture, ethics, residence, relation to ourselves & others

CF.content: all Nation-States founded in violence, all culture a type of colonialism > foundation scripted into State order to hide itself, sublimation/celebration of beginning as amnesia
CF.linkedContent: all Nation-States founded in violence, all culture a type of colonialism > foundation scripted into State order to hide itself, sublimation/celebration of beginning as amnesia

BSi.content: the (mis)translation of logos brings w/ it the whole of culture; whole force of history at work to produce this translation [logos as Christ] > whole of history at play in motif of beast & sovereign and their relation to zoōn: “there are no limits, no frontiers that can contain these issues of translation”
BSi.linkedContent: the (mis)translation of logos brings w/ it the whole of culture; whole force of history at work to produce this translation [logos as Christ] > whole of history at play in motif of beast & sovereign and their relation to zoōn: “there are no limits, no frontiers that can contain these issues of translation”

OG.content: Hegel: learn to read and write as a means to infinite culture
OG.linkedContent: Hegel: learn to read and write as a means to infinite culture

OG.content: writing as criterion of historicity or cultural value
OG.linkedContent: writing as criterion of historicity or cultural value

OG.content: forget different remedies, is the tarantula bite itself different in different cultures?
OG.linkedContent: forget different remedies, is the tarantula bite itself different in different cultures?
